fields.description:
when using IDEA 10 intergrated with Jira, Jira access log file exposed user password.

When we are investigating some other issue, we found some user's username and password are exposed in the access log file like:

10.10.100.100 678x46668x1 Username [11/Mar/2011:11:18:14 -0500] "GET /sr/jira.issueviews:searchrequest-xml/temp/SearchRequest.xml?tempMax=50&assignee=Username&reset=true&sorter/field=updated&sorter/order=DESC&pager/start=0&os_username=Username&os_password=UserPassword HTTP/1.1" 200 247717 763 "-" "Jakarta Commons-HttpClient/3.1" "i66j0u"



checked with those users, turned out they are using a IDEA 10 feature to integrate with Jira.
fields.summary: Security problem when integrate IDEA 10 with Jira

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
create an issue (e.g. bug) and give it one character summary equal A
(just capital A - one character)
Then try to find such issue using JQL, e.g:

summary ~= "A"
or
summary ~= "\"A\""

JQL finds nothing.
Tested on JAC.
E.g. try to find http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/TST-25122

Interestingly when the summary is just B or C or whatever - it works.
fields.summary: JQL does not find issues which have summary = "A"

fields.description:
Try to create new project and use image from local computer as project avatar.  

When submitting the form, browser will display pop asking "Are you sure you want to navigate away from this page"?
fields.summary: "Are you sure you want to navigate away from this page" when creating project with "Custom Avatar" in Firefox

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-23914].
  {panel}

Hello,
I would like to have REST access to JIRA, enabling full remote admin (including greenhopper). 
This would allow to automate standard admin tasks and eliminate many errors.
SOAP allows only a subset of admin tasks and is not really an alternative.
Thanks
fields.summary: JIRA + Greenhopper REST  access

fields.description:
Go to JIRA in a "fresh" browser (e.g. a new private browsing window, or clear cached data). 

Open an issue.  The "Sub-Tasks" division shows the list of subtasks, and a "+" icon.  Click the "+" icon to show the "Create Sub-Task Form".  There is now no button to hide the "Create Sub-Task".   

NOTE: The downwards-arrow hides the *entire* "Sub-Tasks" division, including the existing subtasks.  I want to hide only the "Create Sub-Task" section of the division.

Expected Behaviour: After click "+" to show "Create Sub-Task" in addition to sub-task list, I expect a button to hide it again.

Actual Behaviour: No such button exists, the only nearby button (down-arrow icon) will hide the entire Sub-Task pane including all sub-tasks.

I have attached "before" and "after" screenshots.   Clicking the "+" goes from before to after, but there is no way to go back to the "before" state.
fields.summary: "Create Sub-Task" form in parent issue, once shown, cannot be hidden again

fields.description:
# Goto an issue
# Start typing something into the comment box at the bottom of the page (don't submit)
# Open the log work dialog.
# Try and submit some work. You will be presented with the famous "dirty form warning".
# Click "Stay on Page".
# (BUG) The dialog is left open even though we have created the worklog entry. The "log" button is disabled. You can only cancel out of the dialog.

I would expect that we behave better. Specifically, I would expect the dialog to close and a message to be displayed saying that the worklog entry was created but is not being displayed. Maybe something a little simpler would also be better.
fields.summary: The "Dirty Form" warning behaves strangely (incorrectly?) with dialogs.
4.3 Upgrade Guide: remove "*This does not apply to the final JIRA 4.3 release.*" [ON DAY OF LAUNCH]

fields.description:
Orignally reported by American Family Insurance Group, ticket #26169672.  Client reported that an old "Daily Active Directory & Member Server Compliance Event Summary" report from 2/25/11 contains data from 2/24/11 but also old data from previous months. 

You can see the old data by viewing the completed report for that day:
1) Go to portal, click on Reports tab -> Completed
2) Find "Daily Active Directory & Member Server Compliance Event Summary" for Fri Feb 25 09:24:18 PM 2011 
3) Click "View" link next to report
4) Select the below Event IDs to see examples of what we believe to be "old" data
Event ID# 74092206, Dec 25
Event ID# 74092349, Dec 27
Event ID# 74092678, Dec 28
Event ID# 74094642, Jan 12
Event ID# 74095079, Jan 14
Event ID# 74095425, Jan 16
Event ID# 74097447, Feb 3
Event ID# 74099428, Feb 21
Event ID# 74099483, Feb 22

This does not seem to be an ongoing problem with reports run since then.
fields.summary: Report contains some old data out of date range

fields.description: Would be cool to have the complete issue history available through a remote API. This would make it possible, among other things, to build proper burndown charts and other dashboards for JIRA Studio - where you don't allow custom plugins, making RPC the only way to compensate for numerous Greenhopper math issues.
fields.summary: Make issue history available through RPC (SOAP, REST)

fields.description:
In the page header the space between the logo and user name is totally wasted (unless maybe when you have a logo that stretches to the right way too much).
I find myself needing to have an announcement banner for longer time and not just temporary. For example I changed our Jira helpdesk email address from x to y and like to announce that for 6 months. It is nice to be able to use the header which is empty. 
Maybe you can allow for a special type of announcement banner that is short and also scrolling. 
Or maybe we can consolidate the 2 headers into one. Logo header with Jira popups header. 

The UI design can do better job at using the header space. 
See attached for an example.
fields.summary: Use the space between the Logo and the user name more effectivley.

fields.description:
Jira is very chatty with Crowd, see: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CWDSUP-4148
One request is sent to crowd per request into jira.

Something like: com.atlassian.crowd.integration.service.cache.CacheAwareAuthenticationManager should be used.

We have a similar issue with Confluence.
fields.summary: Cache Crowd Authentication on the client side

fields.description:
When a major configuration change is made on a system, the application displays a info box at the top of Admin pages suggesting that a re-index should be performed.  This information is displayed to users that do not have the permission to run a re-index.

When a Project Administrator goes into the Administration page they see this message.  This message should only be displayed to users that are in the jira-administrators group.  Since the person is not in the group they should not be able to see the message.
fields.summary: Hide Re-Indexing after Major Configuration Change Information Box

fields.description:
It would be useful to customize the colours of the user interface.
For example, having white fonts over dark background, etc.
An example is the themes feature of Google Mail.
fields.summary: Add colour themes

fields.description: If the custom field option has the value of the tab (see screenshot tab_value.png), you won't be able to use the option for the issue (see screenshot tab_error.png). The tab value will not be shown in the browser (see screenshot options_view.png) but can be checked in the database.
fields.summary: Unable to use the option in custom field if the option has tab value "\t" in the string

fields.description:
For JIRA 3.13.x, 4.0.x, 4.1.x, 4.2.x and 4.3 rc1:
Radio Buttons, Multi Select, Cascading Select, Multi Checkboxes, Select List contents will be broken/missing when exported to Excel if it has "<123 ... 456>" (see screenshot radio_button.png). Evey thing after "<123" or in between "<123...345>" will be missing in excel export (see screenshot excel_export.png). 

For JIRA 4.1.x, 4.2.x and 4.3 rc1:
Multi Select and Multi Checkboxes don't have the error if the next option after the problematic option are selected (see screenshot options.png). It will still have the error if the next option is not selected (see screenshot not_selected.png)
fields.summary: Excel export broken due to the content "<123 ... 456>"

fields.description:
We are using the commit acceptance plugin with svn. Current rules only allow to filter "unresolved" issues. In our workflow, we need to allow commits only if the issue is in (a) given state(s). We cannot rely on developers (we have several hundreds of them) to force themselves to check if the issue they refer to is in "allowed" state. 
So this kind of condition is missing to the acceptance plugin. Which states are valid should be configurable in the Commit Acceptance Jira user interface.
fields.summary: Commit Acceptance plugin should accept issue key only when it is in certain workflow states

fields.description:
Hi,

I just recognized a misbehaviour in this Jira. To reproduce this do the following:

1. Go on a project in Jira and open the overview.
2. Change to another tab, e.g. Roadmap
3. Try to change the project with going on the arrow new "Projects" in the main menu.

There should be displayed [object Object]. (See attachment firstClick.bmp)

If you click again on the arrow then the list of the recent projects are displayed. (See attachment secondClick.bmp)

Regards
Christina

To reproduce
# log into jira.atlassian.com
# click Add Gadget
# type _map_ in the search box in the Gadget Directory (directory reduces to 2 items)
# click the X to clear the search box in the Gadget Directory

*Expected Result* directory resets and all the gadgets are displayed again
*Actual Result* nothing happens. I'm still looking at 2 gadgets that contain the word _map_

This happens on our Jira 4.1.2 instance, too.

fields.description:
This is caused by a ThreadLocal not being cleared correctly after a request. Requests that subsequently run on the same thread may receive a stale bean that was left over by another thread.

This affects the {{ContextUriInfo}} bean (used to build self links in the REST plugin) and the {{ContextI18n}} bean (used to build i18n'ed messages).
fields.summary: Beans with scope="restmethod" can leak from one request to the other

fields.description: In Studio, we need to disable web sudo until all products support web sudo. We try to do this in a plugin upgrade task but it appears that the 'websudo-disabled' option is cached in InternalWebSudoManagerImpl class, and it requires restarting JIRA to pick the new setting up from database.
fields.summary: Web sudo setting is cached

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-23885].
  {panel}

If a plug-in which supplies a Workflow condition is removed from JIRA (or disabled in JIRA),
and that condition is currently being used by a Workflow transition,
any step which uses that transition to reach another step will not render any of the possible transitions.

Similarly, if validators or post-functions are missing, no warnings are visible in the UI though the transitions do appear.

No feedback is given to the user that an issue has occurred, but all transitions are absent.

Recommended behavior: 
1) Log an error in the JIRA log (if not done already)
2) Display a warning to the end user to contact their system administrator, and that a "Workflow Configuration Error: A plug-in with a Workflow Transition used by this Workflow is missing from JIRA" with any additional details (name of plug-in, etc) that can be provided.
fields.summary: Workflow Transition Behavior if a Condition, Validator, or Post Function Plug-in Is Missing

fields.description:
In the REST plugin we have a 'restmethod' scope that allows components to be injected from the current request. Its currently broken:

- The scope is implemented via an REST interceptor (RequestScopeInterceptor). The problem is that the REST plugin does not fire the interceptor for all requests. For example, it is not triggered when doing an attachment.
- The scope is not correctly cleared after the request is finished which can leave invalid stuff in the scope for the next request (its in a thread local).

I tried to quickly to fix the second problem above and it exposed the second problem. The fix will 99% require a fix of the REST plugin or us to implement the 'restmethod' scope without using the interceptors.
fields.summary: JIRA REST Plugin does not clear its 'restscope' correctly.

fields.description:
Hello Guys,

Got this one from a ticket, and it is easily reproduceable by following these steps:
{quote}
    * Create a JIRA Administrator and login with this user (admin.jira)
    * Create a copy of jira workflow (jira_copy)
    * Add to Create Issue transition (on jira_copy workflow) a Permission Validator by selecting "Administer Projects" on validator screen.
    * Create a Workflow Scheme (workflow_test) and choose jira_copy workflow for Sub-task issues and jira workflow for Unassigned Types.
    * Create a new Project (TEST) and associate workflow_test to the project.
    * Create a new user (devel.jira) and add it as member of jira-users and jira-developers groups. The user admin.jira should be member of jira-users, jira-developers and jira-administrators.
    * Create a new issue (TEST-1)
    * Create a Sub-task for this issue (TEST-2)
    * Logout and login again as devel.jira
    * Go to issue TEST-1 and Clone the issue checking "Clone Sub Tasks". The user devel.jira has the permission to clone this issue but not to pass the validator on Create Sub-task transition (it is not an administrator).
    * As result you can find the issue TEST-3 where the Sub-task is the issue itself (TEST-3).
{quote}

The result, where the subtask is the parent issue itself, cannot be fixed when trying to delete any of these 2 tasks. When trying, this message appears:
{code}
The JIRA server was contacted but has returned an error response. We are unsure of the result of this operation.

Close this dialog and press refresh in your browser
{code}

And none of the issues are deleted.

The only workaround to fix this problem is direct database change:
{code}
    * delete the issue on db using DELETE FROM JIRAISSUE WHERE PKEY=<issuekey>
    * restart JIRA and run the Integrity Checker (fix the link associations)
    * reindex JIRA issues.
{code}

But I cannot understand why this problem is created in the first place. I think it has something to do with the create issue validator, when it is applied to sub-tasks.

Cheers

Thiago Prisco
Atlassian Support
fields.summary: Validators used with Subtasks, when cloning the parent issues, causes inconsistencies
This is a new SOAP issue 3/8/2011 4:54:48 AM

fields.description:
One of our plugin upgrade tasks needs to create a new user group. But it fails with a message:
{code}com.atlassian.crowd.exception.runtime.OperationFailedException: No Crowd Application available.{code}

This is because the 'embedded_crowd' application is not found.

After reading the log, it turns out that the 'embedded_crowd' application is added by JIRA's own upgrade task 601, which is run after the plugin upgrade tasks are run.

The PluginUpgradeManager listens to JiraStartedEvent, which is fired at the end of ComponentManager.quickStart(), which is part of the ConsistencyLauncher, which runs before UpgradeLauncher that runs JIRA's own upgrade tasks.
fields.summary: Plugin System upgrade tasks should not be run before JIRA's own upgrade tasks are run

fields.description:
Initially raised in EAP feedback:
http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-23033?page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel&focusedCommentId=231531#comment-231531

There are a couple of scenarios where we know it is not possible for a user's password to be changed from within JIRA:
* When the user comes from Read Only LDAP directory
* When the user lives in "Internal Directory with LDAP Auth"
* Can fail under a Crowd Directory - but we don't know beforehand :(

And we can change passwords in the following places:
* Admin can change a user's password
* User can change their own password
* User can make a "reset password" request when they forget password.
This one is a little tricky and probably requires an amended email message.

When this work is completed, I think we can remove the global "External Password Management" setting that is a hangover of OSUser delegated LDAP.
fields.summary: JIRA should not try to change passwords for users that belong to Read Only user directories.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-23862].
  {panel}

Hello,

Since JRA-21004 we no longer have *automatic* (anonymized) exports of jira data attached when filing a support request from jira.

If we file a support request now, we have to *manually* create a data export and attach it to the support case.

This is all working fine and it's not a problem to create a *manual* export.

However, the data export we create this way (*manually*) is *not* anonymized. We can anonymize it by using: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Anonymising+data?utm_source=support

However, this involves some handwork in a terminal window/command prompt.

My suggestion is to add an option the *manual* data export functionality to be able to anonymize the export. 

Also see: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-74677
fields.summary: Add option to anonymize (manual) Data export

fields.description:
An admin can log into JIRA through an Internal Directory, then add an LDAP directory, and push this LDAP directory up to the top of the directory list.

If they don't have the required group memberships in the LDAP directory, they may no longer have admin permissions, or even permission to log in.
You could now be in a position where there are no users in JIRA with admin permission.

Note that there are already restrictions in place to stop admins from editing an LDAP directory that they are logged in through.
fields.summary: An admin can lock themselves out of JIRA by changing the order of the User Directories.

fields.description:
In JIRA 4.2, delegated LDAP would fall back to internal authentication if a user was not present in the directory. In JIRA 4.3, this is not the case.

Please note that the upgrade task will be fixed in v4.3.1 so that we put the users with LDAP accounts into the "Internal Directory with LDAP authentication" and we put the local users into a second "Internal" user directory.
We recommend that anyone with mixed users should *NOT* upgrade to v4.3(.0), and should wait until v4.3.1 instead.
(If you up to 4.3 and then to 4.3.1, you will not get the fix - the fix only happens when the upgrade tasks run, and in this case it is too late)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-23856].
  {panel}

The trusted apps current application keys are stored in a lazy reference in DefaultCurrentApplicationFactory.  They are not reset by a cache cleared event, and there is no way to refresh the keys without restarting JIRA.  This causes a problem in JIRA Studio where we have often needed to refresh keys.  Use cases as follows:

* Security breach requires resetting of all secrets
* A customers import contains their old keys, which poses security risks to both Atlassian and the customer
* Studio changes the way keys are managed to a shared key between all apps

Since the keys are stored in ApplicationProperties, it is simple for Studio to set/change them, however, those changes won't be picked up until JIRA has restarted.  This request is specifically for a mechanism to clear the cache without restarting JIRA.
fields.summary: No way to refresh trusted apps current application keys

fields.description:
On behalf of a customer (Adam Nachman):
{quote}
I understand that the features technically all exist, but as you can see they are a little cumbersome to use. The current process is:

1. Clone issue.
2. Copy original issue number.
3. Link new issue to old.
4. Edit new issue.
5. Move new issue to different project.

Let me flesh out the process to make it clearer:

1. Select "Clone and Link" from "More Actions" menu when viewing a single issue.
2. Select "new issue depends on original".
3. Check "move to project" and select new project.
4. Select new issue type (i.e. was Epic, new is Story).
5. Edit summary and/or description.
6. Edit custom fields, such as "Story points" - which fields are available for editing at this point would be driven by a template, much like the template for the views in the Greenhopper plugin that we use.
7. Click save.

New issue will be cloned to the target project with a link to the original issue, with the changed fields as described above.

This is especially useful when breaking an existing issue, story, feature or improvement up into subtasks or related stories and making the linking simpler to provide traceability.

What was previously a 5 step process now becomes one.
{quote}
fields.summary: Improvements to Issue Cloning feature, by optionally allowing user to move cloned issue to another project, link cloned issue and edit issue fields, before clicking "Create"

Housing an internal blog with wordpress, we wanted to show the latest blog entries on the Jira dashboard. The [wp-igoogle plugin|http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/wp-igoogle/] provides a gadget for a wordpress installation.

Adding its URL to Jira gadget gallery works, but loading and showing the actual feed content fails because the "makeRequest" returns an error:
{code}
HTTP Status 400 - com.sun.syndication.io.ParsingFeedException: Invalid XML
type Status report
message com.sun.syndication.io.ParsingFeedException: Invalid XML
description The request sent by the client was syntactically incorrect (com.sun.syndication.io.ParsingFeedException: Invalid XML).
Apache Tomcat/6.0.20
{code}

This error message does not help debugging the issue because it lacks important information:
- Which XML is invalid? (URL)
- Where is it invalid? (Line and column)


The Jira URL displaying the error in our case is
https://ourjira/jira/plugins/servlet/gadgets/makeRequest?refresh=3600&url=http%3A%2F%2Fourblog%2Ffeed%2F&httpMethod=GET&headers=&postData=&authz=&st=&contentType=FEED&numEntries=5&getSummaries=true&signOwner=true&signViewer=true&gadget=http%3A%2F%2Fourblog%2Fwp-content%2Fplugins%2Fwp-igoogle%2Figoogle.php%3Ft%3D.xml&container=atlassian&bypassSpecCache=

fields.description:
SAL restricts the size of keys which can be used to store data in PluginSettings to a 100 characters. This causes the UAL plugin to fail.
This is too strict and might also cause problems with other plugins.

The problem with UAL appeared after the jira-fisheye-plugin has upgraded existing fisheye repository configurations to UAL. We end up with keys which are exceeding 100 characters to store this data. I'm still investigating this issue. The UAL plugin has to be fixed to generate shorter keys.

How to test this:

# Create an Application Link to FeCru instance, the URL can point to an invalid host, so UAL cannot detect which FeCru repositories are actually available
# Create a link from a JIRA Project to a FeCru repository using the application link you created in the first step
# Use a key which exceeds 19 characters
# Delete the Application Link you created

The delete should succeed w/o any error.
When deleting the application link UAL also deletes the entity link for this application link.
When deleting the application link UAL uses a property key to check "custom properties" for this entity link, this key will get longer than 100 characters if the key of the entity exceeds 19 characters.
fields.summary: Deleting of Application Link fails, because SAL does not allow anymore keys longer than 100 characters.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-23817].
  {panel}

I have an active workflow that I'm modifying in a draft of it (current functionality from JIRA). Everything is great so far and I'm ready to test my draft workflow but my only option is to publish it which will update the live workflow. It does provide an option to backup the current one, which is good, but ususlly is not possible to test workflow on the live system. 

There is a workaround for this but it could be better. Here's my only way to do it so far:
1) Modify the workflow (creating a draft)
2) Copy the draft into a new workflow
3) Create a dummy project to test it

If there are no issues with the workflow is just a matter of publishing the draft. The issue comes if there are problems in the workflow draft and you need to modify it. You have the option of deleting the copy and repeating the above process or modify the copy until you are sattiesfied and carefully make the draft match the copy.

This is probably a feature request or enhancement.
fields.summary: Ability to test draft of workflow before publishing

fields.description:
In the last 3 weeks, we've had 3 separate individuals who are members of the Jira-administrators group carry out a re-index accidentally.
They did so through the notification dialog that appears in all admin screen after making a change that requires a re-index.

We've got 3 jira system admins, and about 10 jira admins.
We've tried to educate people on why they should not hit the re-index button, but the fact that the warning is present on all admin screens means people are more prone to inadvertently clicking it.

So I propose two possible solutions:
1. The re-index permission should only be granted to users in the jira systems admins group
2. The notification for a re-index should only appear to Jira system administrators.

1 would be great, 2 would be a reasonable compromise.

Alternatively, if you guys could break out permissions for each of the admin tasks, so that Jira administrators could offer more granularity, that would be fantastic. Most of the time, we grant people Jira admin permission because they need user/group permissions. They don't need any of the other permissions that being a jira-admin grants.
fields.summary: Only users with Jira System Administrator privileges should be able to re-index

fields.description:
When jira starts with an expired license, it (correctly) prevents jira upgrade tasks from being run. However, plugins start, and some plugins will run their own upgrade tasks. This causes problems as the database in in an inconsistent state at that point.

Jira should provide an api for plugins to check if Jira has been upgraded, so that plugin upgrade tasks can be turned off if necessary. E.g., {{JiraSetupUtils.isDatabaseUpgraded()}}.

-------
from:
https://jdog.atlassian.com/browse/JRADEV-4792
fields.summary: Add an api for plugins to call to check whether jira's DB has been upgraded, so that plugins don erroneously run upgrade tasks.

fields.description:
The documentation at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA040/Advanced+Searching?clicked=jirahelp is incorrect with respect to queries involving DATE fields. It says the following:
{quote}
Find issues that were resolved in January 2009:
resolved > "2008/12/31" and resolved < "2009/02/01"
Find issues that were resolved on 15 January 2009:
resolved > "2009/01/14" and resolved < "2009/01/16"
{quote}
However, the first query will return bugs resolved on "2008/12/31," which is not in January. The second query will return bugs resolved on January 15 *and* January 14.

It seems that {quote}resolved > "2008/12/31"{quote} means "after midnight 31 December 2008." That is, there is an implicit time component of midnight in all DATE fields when none is explicitly specified.  This should be reflected in your documentation. I would also include examples that include a time component.

Thanks.
fields.summary: JQL documentation has errors about how dates are handled

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-23798].
  {panel}

The slow queries log is a really useful tool, but it could be made a little more useful if the number of results returned was appended to the end of each log entry.

The background for this is that we use the Confluence jiraissues macro heavily, and on occasion someone creates a JQL query that returns far far too many results. Jira doesn't actually choke on the query, but it gets hammered trying to read the DB, convert and then feed the XML results back to Confluence.

I was going to suggest just appending the result size to the end of each of the slow query entries, but I thought there's quite a strong chance that the query itself might not take that long. It's the time taken to feed up the XML results that kill us. So it may be better to log all queries that return great than a set threshold of results (like 10,000 for example)

I think this problem+enhancement applies to all situations where Jira is not paging a result set. So I'm guessing XML, RSS, Excel, Word, Full Content, and Printable views get hit with this kind of issue.
fields.summary: Enhance slow queries log or create a new "large resultset" log to log queries that return above a threshold number of results
